intro: Cirsium rhiphaeum, commonly known as the rough thistle, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Asteraceae family. It is native to Europe and parts of Asia, often found in grasslands, meadows, and disturbed soils. The plant is characterized by its spiny, lobed leaves and purple to pink flower heads that bloom in summer. Its leaves are covered in fine hairs and have a rough texture, contributing to its common name. The plant produces achene fruits, which are dispersed by wind, aiding in its spread across various habitats.
